title-group.article-title: Adding Dietary Green Beans to Formula Resolves the Diarrhea Associated With a Bowel Resection in Neonates

abstract.p: Background. Traditionally, dietary fiber has been empirically added to infant formulas to improve feeding intolerance for those infants diagnosed with intestinal failure (IF) or short-bowel syndrome (SBS). Clinicians have added a variety of products such as pectin, Benefiber, infant cereals, or baby foods as the dietary fiber source, without documented evidence of their efficacy. Materials and Methods. This was a retrospective cohort review of infants admitted between August 2003 and June 2011 to the Children’s Hospital of Illinois who had dietary green beans added to their formula because of feeding intolerance. Our primary hypothesis was that adding dietary fiber as green beans to an infant’s formula would correct diarrhea resulting from a bowel resection and reduce their dependence on parenteral nutrition (PN). Results. In all, 18 infants were prescribed dietary green beans added to their formula during this study period; 7 of them were diagnosed with SBS. After the addition of the dietary green beans to their formula, all infants had improvements in stool consistency: 56% of the infants had mushy/soft stools, and 44% of the infants had formed stools. Also, 61% of infants had PN discontinued because 100% of their nutritional needs were met by enteral feedings. Conclusion. Infants with IF or SBS stool patterns improved after dietary green beans were added to the formula. The addition of this type of dietary fiber may allow the clinician to advance enteral feeding volumes and decrease the infant’s dependence on PN and avoid associated PN-related morbidities.

disp-quote.p: “A massive bowel resection can inhibit the ability of the gastrointestinal tract to effectively digest and absorb nutrients and/or fluids.”

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Neonates diagnosed with gastrointestinal disorders or necrotic bowel requiring surgical intervention, depending on the severity of the bowel resection, can have greatly reduced surface area. A massive bowel resection can inhibit the ability of the gastrointestinal tract to effectively digest and absorb nutrients and/or fluids. Intestinal failure (IF) is defined as a reduction in the ability of the gut to efficiently digest and absorb fluids and nutrients, leading to a dependence on parenteral nutrition (PN) to meet the nutrition requirements for growth.1,2 Neonates undergoing an extensive bowel resection may be diagnosed with short-bowel syndrome(SBS). SBS is defined as the malabsorptive state that often follows a massive resection, leading to neonates’ inability to maintain their nutrient, electrolyte, and fluid status from a conventional oral diet.3,4 For neonates diagnosed with IF or SBS, PN is initially prescribed as the primary source of nutrition. Although PN can maintain a neonate’s nutritional status, its long-term dependence is associated with morbidities. Neonates who are dependent on long-term PN are at greater risk for developing cholestasis,5-8 osteopenia,9,10 growth failure,11 and sepsis.12 The most severe cases can require intestinal transplantation13 and may result in death.14

The advancement of enteral nutrition is the most effective treatment for preventing and correcting PN-related morbidities because it decreases the infant’s dependence on PN.6,15,16 Unfortunately, feeding intolerance remains one of the most common complications with IF or SBS patients. Feeding intolerance may occur as a result of malabsorption,17,18 hypergastric secretion,19,20 bacteria overgrowth,21 loss of the ileocecal valve,22-24 and hyperosmolar enteral feedings.25 Specialized amino acid–based formulas26-28 and human milk26 have been shown to improve feeding tolerance in neonates with SBS or IF. Even with these specialized formulas, feeding intolerance can still persist, preventing the medical team from advancing enteral feedings and prolonging the use of PN. Clinicians have empirically prescribed adding a dietary fiber source to enteral formulas to improve feeding intolerance such as diarrhea. For adult patients receiving enteral feedings, the addition of dietary fiber can improve stool consistency and relieve diarrhea.29 The addition of dietary fiber for adults with IF or SBS has been shown to improve stool consistency.30,31 There are no studies documenting the effectiveness of dietary fiber in pediatric IF or SBS patients. Dietary fiber has been prescribed in the pediatric population to resolve both infectious and chronic diarrhea. A variety of dietary fiber sources have been utilized as bulking agents, such as green bananas,32,33 pectin,33 guar gum,34,35 and green beans.36 Since 2003, the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit at Children’s Hospital of Illinois (CHOI) have periodically added stage II baby food green beans to an infant’s formula as a dietary fiber source when conventional nutrition interventions for treating neonates with IF or SBS have failed. It has been our observation that after the addition of dietary green beans, the stool consistency improves, allowing clinicians to continue gradually advancing enteral feedings.
The primary hypothesis for this study was that the addition of dietary green beans to a neonate’s formula would resolve the diarrhea associated with a bowel resection.

sec.title: Study Population
sec.p: This is a retrospective cohort study reviewing the medical records of infants admitted to CHOI at OSF Saint Francis Medical Center in Peoria, Illinois. Medical records of 18 infants admitted to CHOI from August 2003 to June 2011 were reviewed. A research nurse and registered dietitian obtained the following information: gestational age at birth, birth weight, classification at birth, gender, race, anthropometrics, surgical diagnosis, removal of bowel, how many centimeters of bowel remaining (if available), diet prescription, feeding mode, stool pattern, serum albumin, serum direct bilirubin, and discharge diet prescription. When dietary greens were prescribed for a patient, the order was written to add 1 jar of stage 2 baby food green beans (Table 1) to every 8 ounces of 30 calorie/ounce formula.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: The χ2 test was used to compare the associations between 2 categorical variables. When there was an empty cell or a small cell, then the Fisher’s exact test was used. Because of this study’s small sample size, the Mann-Whitney U test was used to compare the differences between the 2 groups. Descriptive statistics were used to describe all means, standard deviations, and medians for continuous variables; percentage values were used for categorical variables. The 2-tailed P values are calculated for all tests, and P < .05 was considered to be statistically significant. All statistical analyses were performed using SPSS 17.0 (SPSS Inc, Chicago, IL).

sec.title: Demographics and Surgical Data
sec.p: The mean gestational age at birth (Table 2) was 32.3 ± 5 weeks, with a range between 23 and 39 weeks. The mean birth weight was 1938 ± 1007 g, with a range between 585 to 3507 g. In all, 11 infants (61%) were male, and 7 (39%) were female; 10 infants (56%) were Caucasian, 5 (28%) were African American, 2 (11%) were Hispanic, and 1 (5%) was Asian. Also 16 (89%) of the infants were classified as appropriate for gestational age, whereas 2 infants (11%) were classified as small for gestational age. Regarding diagnoses, 5 infants (28%) requiring surgical intervention were diagnosed with necrotizing enterocolitis, 4 (22%) developed necrotizing enterocolitis with a perforation, 4 (22%) had gastroschisis, 2 (11%) were diagnosed with Christmas Tree Defect, and 3 (17%) had other types of diagnoses; 16 infants (89%) had a portion of their small bowel removed, whereas 4 infants (24%) had a portion of their colon removed. Finally, 8 infants (44%) were diagnosed with SBS, whereas 10 infants (56%) were classified as having IF.

sec.title: Nutrition Management With Green Beans
sec.p: The mean percentage of enteral feeding volume to PN was 78% ± 31% (Table 3); 11 infants (61%) received Peptamen Junior (Nestle, NJ), 5 (28%) received EleCare (Abbott Nutrition, OH), 1 (5%) received Neocate (Nutricia, NJ), and 1 (5%) received a standard-term formula. Also, 13 infants (72%) received bolus feedings, whereas 5 (28%) received continuous feedings. Prior to the dietary green beans being added, 12 infants (67%) had liquid stools, and 6 infants (33%) experienced loose stools. After the stage 2 green beans were added to the infants’ formula, 10 infants’ (56%) stools changed to a mushy/soft consistency, whereas 8 infants (44%) had formed stools.

sec.title: Clinical Outcomes
sec.p: It was found that 14 infants (78%) developed cholestatic jaundice (direct bilirubin > 1.5 g/dL) during their hospitalization, whereas 4 infants (22%) did not develop cholestatic jaundice (Table 4). At the time of discharge, 6 infants (33%) still had cholestatic jaundice, whereas in 12 infants (66%), cholestatic jaundice resolved; 7 infants (39%) were discharged home on PN, whereas 11 infants (61%) were discharged home receiving all their nutrition by enteral feedings. At discharge, 7 infants (44%) received Peptamen Junior (Nestle, NJ), 1 (6%) received Neocate (Nutricia, NJ), 7 (44%) received EleCare (Abbott Nutrition, OH), and 1 (6%) received a standard-term formula. Also, 11 infants (61%) were above the 10th percentile for weight for age at discharge, whereas 4 infants (22%) were below the 10th percentile at discharge for weight for age. The mean weight for infants at discharge was 4447 ± 1180 g, with a range between 2420 and 6730 g. The mean length of stay was 114 ± 75 days, with a range between 44 and 260 days.

sec.title: Comparison Between SBS and IF
sec.p: In all, 9 infants (90%) with IF (Table 5) were able to be weaned off PN prior to discharge versus only 2 infants (25%) with SBS, which was significant (P = .013). Infants with IF received 93% ± 24% of their feeding volume from enteral nutrition, whereas infants with SBS only received 60% ± 31% of their feeding volume from enteral nutrition, which was significant (P = .034). The remaining clinical outcomes for cholestatic jaundice, anthropometrics, and weight at discharge were similar for both groups.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In support of our hypothesis, adding dietary green beans to an infant’s formula improved the stool patterns in neonates who became feeding intolerant as a result of complications associated with a bowel resection. The dietary fiber present in the green beans was probably the primary reason why it was effective at improving stool consistency. The rationale for using green beans was based on the article by Rabbani et al.32 They studied infants with infectious diarrhea and concluded that adding dietary fiber to the infant’s formula could resolve the diarrhea.32 The study was a double-blinded randomized trial of infant boys between the ages of 5 and 12 months old. The randomized participants received either 250 g of cooked, unripened green bananas (plantains) per liter of formula or had 4 g/kg/d of pectin (Sigma, St Louis, MO) added to their formula, whereas the control group received formula without any added dietary fiber.32 By study day 4, those receiving cooked green plantains had a 78% resolution of their symptoms and those who received pectin in their formula had an 82% resolution of their symptoms, unlike the control group, who only had a 23% resolution of symptoms.32 Infants in the green banana group had an average intake of 180 to 200 g (30 g/kg) of cooked green bananas, which was estimated to be equivalent to 1½ to 2 uncooked fruits per day.32

Unfortunately, unripened green bananas are not available in Central Illinois. Another dietary fiber source was investigated as a replacement for green bananas. The neonatal dietitian compared the nutrient analysis of green bananas with different types of commercial baby foods and determined that stage 2 green bean baby food had similar dietary fiber content to the cooked green bananas used by Rabbani et al. The dietary fiber content present in commercial stage 2 green bean baby food averages between 2 to 3 g per 4-ounce jar. The dietary fiber present in green beans is a combination of 32% soluble and 68% insoluble fiber.37

The substances produced from the fermentation of dietary fiber in the colon are short chain fatty acids (SCFAs). The most commonly produced SCFAs are acetate, propionate, and butyrate, which stimulate the absorption of water in the ascending colon. The SCFA produced have a trophic effect on both the colon and the small intestine by enhancing absorption of nutrients and fluids, leading to an antidiarrheal effect.33 SCFAs can significantly increase within 24 hours of digestion of indigestible carbohydrates, especially butyrate plasma concentrations.38 Studies using animal models with SBS showed that adding butyrate to PN improved villi height leading to enhanced enteral tolerance and weaning off PN sooner.39 The trophic effects from SCFA may be why the infants who received green beans in their formula had their stools transitioned from liquid/loose to mushy/formed within 24 hours. In another study by Rabbani et al,33 infants with infectious diarrhea were given a dietary fiber source either as green bananas or pectin added to their formula, which improved the intestinal permeability of the small intestine. Rabbani et al found that both green bananas and pectin fibers decreased the urinary lactulose excretion, improved mannitol excretion, and significantly reduced the lactulose-mannitol ratio when compared with infants in the control group.33

The type of feeding mode can affect a clinician’s ability to advance enteral feedings. Providing continuous infusion of enteral nutrition to infants with IF or SBS can lead to better gut adaptation. Patients with a massive bowel resection and limited surface area will still be dependent on PN for a majority of their nutritional intake even when continuous enteral feedings are given. Previous case reports and retrospective studies have suggested that infants with IF or SBS can have improved feeding tolerance when receiving either an amino acid–based formula or human milk.26-28 In our study, several types of enteral formulas were utilized, but currently, it is the practice of our unit to use an amino acid–based formula for infants with IF or SBS that is administered continuously over 24 hours.

Infants with IF were able to tolerate significantly more enteral feeding volumes than infants with SBS. Infants with IF had increased enteral feeding volumes when compared with infants with SBS, allowing for increased opportunity for PN to be discontinued. The length of residual bowel after initial surgery remains a key variable in determining how long an infant with SBS will remain dependent on PN.40-42

The limitations with this study are the small sample size and the retrospective design. Also, the heterogeneity of the population, with different diagnoses, extent of bowel resection, and degree of prematurity, may have affected the results and outcomes. The feeding mode was varied between patients, which may have affected the infant’s ability to be weaned off PN. Another limitation was that there was no follow-up after discharge home on the long-term impact dietary green beans had on outcomes. A randomized controlled trial is needed to determine what beneficial affects dietary fiber has in improving feeding tolerance and decreasing dependence on PN for infants with SBS or IF.

Infants with IF or SBS had improved stool consistency after dietary green beans were added to their formulas. Although the addition of dietary green beans did not eliminate all infants’ needs for supplemental PN, it did decrease their dependence on PN, reducing their risk for PN-related complications. Clinicians should consider prescribing dietary green beans as a source of dietary fiber when conventional feeding practices are ineffective at treating IF- or SBS-related feeding intolerance.
